subject: History
title: Imperial Rivalries in Africa
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Imperial Rivalries in Africa.

hook.text: European empires carved up Africa at a conference in Berlin. The resentments they created helped start a world war.

buildup.text: The 1884 Berlin Conference divided Africa among European powers. By 1914, 90% of the continent was colonized.

discovery.text: France and Germany nearly went to war twice over Morocco in 1905 and 1911â€”colonial ambition on a collision course.

twist.text: These crises didn't start WWI directly but hardened alliances, deepened distrust, and made compromise impossible.

climax.text: By 1914, imperial rivalries had transformed European diplomacy from cooperation into an armed standoff.

punchline.text: Africa was the stage. Europe was the powder keg.

quiz.question: How did the Moroccan Crises of 1905 and 1911 contribute to World War I?
options: They directly triggered the war's first battles
They hardened alliances and deepened distrust between nations
They led to Morocco joining the war on Germany's side
